abstracts.cdata!:
The Colombo Urban Transport
            Project's outcome was rated as satisfactory. Key
            lessons learned from the project include: 1) As a project
            evolves during identification, preparation and appraisal, it
            is important that a realistic match is maintained between
            project components, objectives and indicators. 2) The Bank
            must be realistic about results of institutional
            strengthening. Changing a government department into a
            supposedly autonomous body would be unlikely to have a
            noticeable impact on efficiency unless this was accompanied
            by a deregulation of service provision and tariff setting;
            and genuine autonomy regarding cost control, use of
            revenues, and access to capital markets. 3) It is important
            to avoid having too many implementing agencies involved with
            the project, which weakened the impact of Bank discussion
            with the government on project matters and policy reforms.
            4) Projects are more effective if they are being implemented
            by an established unit as part of the regular work program
            of the executing agency. The project can then contribute
            directly to the institutional strengthening of that agency.
            5) Bids for major civil works and goods and proposals for
            major consultancy studies should be obtained before board
            presentation. The procurement process needs to be well
            advanced by the time of negotiations, particularly in
            countries where procurement is a slow process.
